variant.question: Anxiety and fear can cause

In order to provide an adequate "buffet boundary" at the commencement of the cruise a speed of 1.3 V~S~ is used. At a mass of 120000 kg this is a CAS of 180 knots. If the mass of the aeroplane is increased to 135000 kg the value of 1.3 V~S~ will be

options.text: increased to 191 knots, drag will increase and air distance per kg of fuel will decrease.
unaffected as V~S~ always occurs at the same angle of attack.
increased to 202 knots but, since the same angle of attack is used, drag and range will remain the same.
increased to 191 knots, drag will decrease and air distance per kg of fuel will increase.

 At a mass of 120000 kg this is a CAS of 180 knots

options.text: increased to 191 knots, drag will increase and air distance per kg of fuel will decrease.
increased to 191 knots, drag will decrease and air distance per kg of fuel will increase.

variant.question: A pilot can overcome hyperventilation by

options.text: controlling the rate and depth of breathing.
increasing the rate and depth of breathing to eliminate harmful carbon dioxide.
the use of drugs that stabilise blood pressure.

variant.question: What are the possible consequences for an aircraft encountering wind shear on final approach?

options.text: The aeroplane stalls when tailwind increases.
The aeroplane tends to dive when crosswind increases.
Turbulence will be felt but there are no other hazards.
The aeroplane stalls when headwind increases.

options.text: tend to go below the glidepath.
have an increased rate of descnt.

variant.question: An aeroplane maintains straight and level flight at a speed of 2 VS. If, at this speed, a vertical gust causes a load factor of 2, the load factor n caused by the same gust at a speed of 1.5 VS would be:

options.text: not greater than 1,75, because the aeroplane is stalled with a higher load factor at 1.5 VS.

variant.question:
An aircraft in a steady, level cruise is experiencing moderate turbulence. The pilot observes a rapid reduction in IAS towards zero. All other instrument indications are unchanged.  
What action should be taken?

options.text: Ensure that the existing aircraft attitude and thrust settings remain unchanged.
Switch off anti-icing equipment, which may have malfunctioned.
Immediately pitch the aircraft down to avoid a stall.
Immediately apply full power to restore IAS

variant.question: On final approach to land you encounter a microburst and you have to go around. What is the risk of flying in these conditions?

options.text: Only light turbulence may be encountered.

As the stability of an aeroplane decreases:

options.text: its tendency to tuck under decreases.
there is no effect on its stability.

variant.question: As the stability of an aeroplane increases:

options.text: its tendency to tuck under increases.
there is no effect on its stability.

variant.question: If a turbulent gust causes an aeroplane to roll:

options.text: the up-going wing experiences an increase in angle of attack.
the angle of attack depends on whether the aeroplane changes speed.
the up-going wing does not experience any change in angle of attack.
the up-going wing experiences a decrease in angle of attack.

options.text: VRA is the recommended turbulence penetration air speed.

variant.question: Which of these statements concerning flight in turbulence is correct?

options.text: The load factor in turbulence may fluctuate above and below 1 and can even become negative.

When encountering turbulence during flight, the speed should be adjusted to the design speed for maximum gust intensity V~B~.
In severe turbulence, speed should be reduced to approximately 1.2 V~S~.
